pros: Tuition assistance. Working for the state means you get some paid leave if you have a baby.
cons: Management is very top-heavy. Lots of executive directors, AVPS, and VPs, but refuse to hire people to do the actual work. Current employees are asked to do more and more without any additional compensation or discussion of hiring help. Leadership has zero respect for anyone outside their inner circle and there is little to no communication anywhere on campus. Employees have no idea what is happening, but what is shared with the public is rarely accurate. Pay is horrible unless you are a top-level person. Everyone is afraid of retaliation.

pros: Students are great. Colleagues are generous and welcoming.
cons: Administration has stripped everything down to fit their model (and whims). There is a general lack of respect for faculty and staff. Very bottom-line oriented. Budget cuts not based on merit.

pros: Nice benefits along with decent work life balance
cons: long periods of no pay increase

review_title: Low pay, hard work, generally very under appreciated

cons: The other employees in your department look down on you. You are paid far less than other people in the same department and have much more demanding work with greater responsibilities. In the summer the work load in totally unmanageable and they continue to add more work. There is little opportunity to grow in this position and it has a high turn around rate.

review_title: Higher Ed. Great if you want to stay. Difficult if you plan to leave.

pros: Higher Ed jobs in general can provide opportunities to students and recent graduates to learn aspects of a given profession. My time also allowed me to learn skills outside of my actual role due to team members needing support. If my intent was to stay working in the higher ed field, I feel confident I could apply to universities across the US in a variety of roles.
cons: Lack of funding in general can often lead to delays in receiving the tools we need to improve our operations. All of my professional experience has been in higher ed and looking at private sector jobs makes me feel like my experience is lacking.

pros: Good benefits at a student employee, works with your schedule, not too many hours, convenient way to make money while you're in school, save on gas

pros: Opportunity to develop a wide variety of skills applicable to any future career. Constant chances to increase pay, move up in job placement, and learn something new. Make and manage your own schedule and can drop any shift with 2 weeks notice. Supervisors and upper staff know what they're doing. Director (Steven Whitlock) is always receptive to new ideas and always fighting for more quality work environment for everyone, not just upper staff. Trainings have just begun in the last 6 months in an effort to solve some of the cons listed below, but the trainer position is new so there's still some quirks to smooth out. Many opportunities to give feedback which results in positive changes being made.
cons: May have unclear expectations resulting in employees getting in trouble for something they didn't know. Any company who is this receptive to new ideas will naturally cause the expectations and procedures to change constantly. Sometimes these changes are difficult to keep up with. Many of the ResStar positions have only existed for a year, so there is not much training and the job is sometimes unclear and there are still some quirks in the way things are run. Also need to work on police/housing relations more. When UPD doesn't understand ResStar job position and expectations, they don't know how to appropriately interact with us without treating us like just another ignorant resident.

pros: Great atmosphere, fast-paced, learning environment, student-based.
cons: There not too many bad things I would say about it.

pros: Lots of benefits, including free college using the TAP program.
cons: Hard to take time off sometimes, short-staffed. Only one small raise within the past four years despite having excellent performance evaluations.

pros: UWG is a great place to work if you live locally.
cons: No raises for 3 years. Little opportunity for growth unless you know someone.

pros: Stable, Government work, good community in the local departments
cons: Time, low pay with no signs of changing anytime soon, lack of input to university direction

job_title: Student Assistant II in Carrollton, GA
pros: nice but can be better
cons: pay is very horrible lol

review_title: DO NOT TRUST UWG WITH YOUR CAREER
pros: The students are really great kids.
cons: Laid off over 20 tenure track professors in their 2nd year at UWG with no warning in November 2019. Did not consult chairs, did not even consult deans. The President's office just picked disciplines they felt were low priority and let these 20 tenure-track professors go with callous 3 sentence letters. These were young professors doing great work and included teaching award winners, grant holders, and great scholars who were doing exceptional on annual evaluations. Absolutely abhorrent management from Morerro to Crafton to all upper management. If you can work anywhere else as a professor I would recommend you do. Trusting UWG with your career is a mistake, it was the worst mistake of my career. CARES ONLY ABOUT THE BOTTOM LINE, COULD NOT CARE LESS ABOUT THEIR EMPLOYEES. Quite literally destroyed people's lives who had families, who had purchased houses in the area, and who had moved great distances to join UWG. They’ve changed presidents but don’t think they have changed their ways. Do not trust them with your career.

review_title: Look out for yourself first, Go somewhere with longer contract terms
pros:
- Good colleagues
- Great students
- Nice campus
cons:
- Upper management completely untrustworthy (non-renewed a lot of us second year tenure track professors due to lowered enrollment in fall of 2018. They took no other actions. All staff, non-tenure faculty, facility upgrades, etc. went on as scheduled). 
- The school expects a ton of service and that's fine until they unexpectedly let you go. Budget will always be the priority it seems, I've also heard of cases where they go through the hiring process, offer the job and have it accepted,  only to have funding fall through last minute before the semester starts and rescinding job contract. 
- A very conservative state so low pay, no job security, one year contracts that they will tell you are just a formality and that they are committed to you as tenure track but in the end they do this so they have flexibility to let you go.

pros: Plenty of professional development opportunities. Many employees are wonderful and enthusiastic about higher education. Some departments are great places to work with supportive managers and teams that actively work toward student success. Many positions qualify for the Tuition Assistance Program.
cons: Certain departments are absolute nightmares with archaic management styles that stifle employees. Avoid the Registrar’s Office at ALL costs - it has a horrible reputation and a lot of turnover. It is common to overwork employees with little to no recognition or reward, especially in certain Enrollment Management offices.

job_title: Student Teaching Assistant in Villa Rica, GA
pros: Wonderful atmosphere. Gained valuable insight to the struggles of professors in academia, attempting to educate the uncooperative. However, the students interested in investing in themselves and in their future, offset the former. Additionally, as a benefit to this position, the information is cemented into memory once you teach the material to someone else!
cons: Again, the uncooperative students are the only con to this position and are the only drawback. And the Parking situation on campus!

pros:
I enjoyed working with the student population. The campus is filled with many first generation, working class, rural students who are so proud to be on a college campus. They're very eager to learn and get involved. The staff population isn't very diverse, but everyone is friendly and strong advocates of collaboration.
The campus is also beautiful and small enough that everyone feels sort of like family.
cons: It's in the middle of nowhere! I do wonder about the lack of diversity in staff-but it could be that more diverse candidates don't want to be in the in such a rural area.

review_title: Stick to Student Affairs Over SAEM
pros: The experience varies greatly by department, and division. If you are in Academic Affairs as a staff member, you are safely in a much better place than Student Affairs and Enrollment Management. It is without question that certain colleges treat their employees better, and the underlying spoken culture confirms this. If possible, work for the College of Education, Richards College of Business, or e-Core.
cons: Sometimes there is a clear gap between words and actions, leaving some of the entry-level positions to fill in the gaps.

review_title: Great potential for enrichment; tough to get ahead
pros:
- People are great for the most part (avoid certain depts - you'll figure out which ones quickly)
- Offices are very laid back and students/faculty/staff are generally nice
- Good opportunity for training and learning on the job
cons:
- Hard to get ahead (never any raises, hard to get promoted, and leadership is "old guard")
- Tough to make changes (even with good reasoning/logic - see old guard above)

review_title: Great work environment, low pay for middle management and below
job_title: Staff In Division of Student Affairs in Carrollton, GA
pros: Supportive co-workers, talented students, multitude of professional development opportunities, engaged senior administrators,continually evolving and improving, beautiful facilities. Health and dental insurance package is competitive.
cons: With the exception of senior administrators, salaries are quite low.  Raises beyond the Mercer Study are incredibly hard to come by.  Monies can be arranged, but a person who receives a job offer must negotiate extra skillfully to obtain what they are worth...otherwise their salary is likely to remain exactly the same for the next 3 to 5 years despite positive evaluations.

pros:
Flexibility with schedule 
Fun training events
Pay within my department is good, and there is room for grow, within position title and income
Although there are different areas within UREC but there is a huge sense of family among the student
It is the top employer on campus
Lots of nice appeal once you're employed 
Simple job task
Easy to cover someones shift if needed
Top job on campus, every student wants to work at University Recreation Center
cons:
Micro managed with new upper management on board
Students once had a feeling like they were trusted, that's not really the case anymore
Upper management doesn't really recognize how much students really run the facility
There is no employee recognition for all that the students do with programs and the facility as a whole
Previous management is leaving like wildflowers which lets students know that the management office has a lot of issues and the new hires aren't really changing much
Students at most times feel unappreciated
You can't really express concerns without the feeling you might be fired anymore, it hasn't always been like this
As a student you don't know what your boss does because students run everything in the facility
The department is not a strong as it once was two years ago
If you don't suck up to upper management it is hard to get promoted to a student manager position

review_title: Great environment, can be political like any institutional work.
pros:
Flexibility
Benefits, including Health and Vision
Access to Education and Career Development
cons:
Pay is not great unless you're a teacher or senior admin
Inconsistent levels of activity may be jarring -- You'll have extended times where nothing is going on and then, suddenly, everything is vying for your time at once.

review_title: Graduate Research Assistant in the Psychology Department
cons:
- Difficult to work every semester while attending the graduate program due to overwhelming demand;
- By itself, it is difficult to meet the financial demands of school, housing, etc. on the salary paid to students for each semester of work.

pros: Great atmosphere for student workers. Co-workers were mostly friendly and helpful. I was given plenty of freedom to handle my business and had flexible hours. I also had plenty of downtime to complete school work.
cons: The pay wasn't great and certain upper-management people were unfriendly. I was employed here for several years and was not given the option to have a raise in my pay.

pros: Great department for a smaller school.  Decent research, but all undergrads so the focus is on teaching. Friendly people, and supportive staff.
cons: The University is currently bringing us up to 85% of the median pay for similar institutions. So, pay is less than stellar. Student talent pool suffers because of the proximity to GaTech and Emory.

job_title: Physics Lab Teaching Assistant in Carrollton, GA
pros: Wonderful place to work for first job / employment opportunities.
cons: As someone with little experience, I'm not too critical of a place which offers employment opportunities. I don't have anything too harsh to say.

review_title: It has been an enjoyable experience
pros: It is a 8-5 everyday of the week. It is a safe work environment. It is a stable work environment. I don't have to worry about if they are going to collapse cause they are a state school. Frequent off time.
cons: Pay is under average. You are working for a state school so there are certain hoops you have to jump through

pros: Can go back to college for free. The retirement plan is awesome!
cons: The pay is the worst for any higher education institution. They think everyone lives in Carrollton where the school is located but this is far from true. Carrollton has a high crime rate and very old houses, no one wants to have to be stuck living there. It is very difficult to get a promotion lots of friends bringing in unqualified friends.

review_title: A very positive, attuned and familiar experience, UWG provided a comforting and rewarding environment.
pros: Very equal-opportunity, kind and listens to its employees. The campus is easily traversed and gorgeous (especially with their new improvements). Very flexible scheduling. Depending on position there is tuition reimbursement.
cons: Management struggles with seeing subordinates point of view (at times).

pros: Team work, lunch outings, conferences, comp time
cons: micro-managing, stressful work environment for an easy job, high turn over rate in the office, you cant be yourself you have to fit in with the team or some people wont like you.

review_title: Easy job for some extra college cash
job_title: UWGeek Squad Officer in Carrollton, GA
pros: Working on campus you get to interact with the students. They know your priority is school, so the take that into consideration. And usually if you're not busy at work, they may allow you to do your school work.
cons: You are only allowed to work up 20 hours a week, as a student. In some positions, they don't even let you get close to the 20 hour max.

pros:
The job provides flexible hours and will work around your class schedule.

It's on the UWG campus, so their is a short walk to your classes.
cons:
A student assistant can work a maximum of only 20 hours per week.

Most people in ITS are either apathetic or unwilling to learn new technologies.

pros: The faculty and staff that I worked with were very supportive, understanding, and eager to promote my personal growth as a student worker. It felt more as a community instead of a job, wherein I gained lasting mentors due to the culture that the university fosters.
cons: Pay is low, but that is due to the state's regulations of work-study programs not exceeding 20 hours a week

review_title: Pockets of great work ethic and knowledge but little to no collaboration.
pros: The campus is beautiful. There some great leaders and some really skilled/knowledgeable people in some departments. Benefits are good. Things are looking up- the place is getting better each year.
cons: Some groups have poor leaders that really inhibit the moral of their groups. Very hard to work with some groups as they are not interested in collaborating.

pros: Some very nice co workers. Vacation and sick time is nice.
cons: Upper management is the most unfair unprofessional I have ever seen. They would hire people in the door making five dollars more and hour doing same job as you and then ask you to train them. No raises very few oppurtunities to advance. To move up you need to quit and reapply.

pros: As a student assistant in the Computer Science department, you will expand your knowledge and solidify the skills you are currently learning.
cons: The increased work load on top of an already daunting curriculum can be quite overwhelming at times. You can make it, but you have to be hyper vigilant about starting homework and projects on time.

pros: The people are very helpful and easy to get along with. The university provides decent benefits even for part time workers.
cons: Different departments are not always on the same page with policies and procedures so things can get a bit challenging at times.

pros: Benefits and PTO. Flexible scheduling if you have other commitments. Free education to employees. Great teamwork in some departments. Professional development is offered on many occasions.
cons: Lack of communication between different departments. Lack of advancement at certain times. Lack of proper training in some areas. Senior Managment does not always take suggestions from lower level employees.

pros: Small town with a beautiful campus
cons: Poor management, who you know matters over results, little interest in improvement

pros: If you can get a full time job I'm sure it's a great place. Everyone seems nice and they put a lot of effort into helping students and employees.
cons: As a part time instructor I did not get much assistance and the pay is low for the amount of work I have to put in.

review_title: Treats faculty and staff like dirt!
pros: Small town so short commute
cons:
Underpaid by about $30,000
Never worked anywhere that had less respect or concern for its faculty and staff
Forces faculty to donate to university and to “tattle” on students
4 raises in 13 years (if .9% can be called a raise). No cost of living adjustments
$4400  insurance deductible

review_title: This is a pretty easy job
pros: Very flexible with scheduling. Not to fast paced except in extreme situations.
cons: Not much room for advancement. Can’t work over 20 hours as a student assistant.

pros: The campus is beautiful!  The people are wonderful.  You get a feeling of being part of a large family by working at UWG.  Something for everyone.  Full time, part time, temporary positions.  Great benefits for full time employees!
cons: Parking for faculty and staff is limited.

pros: If you are in the CS Grad program, there is a discount on the tuition you have to pay.
cons: Unstable upper management. My boss had his position dissolved, they transferred him to a new position, but didn't hire a replacement. This left all Graduate Assistants and Student Assistants unpaid for weeks.

pros: Worked with great professors who were considerate and willing to help you whenever you needed.
cons: The university limits hours to 40 and the number of positions, 2, you can have on campus as a student employee.

pros: The CAS provides students of the University of West Georgia with the best academic support in as many formats as possible, from tutoring to study habits.
cons: There are truly no cons to working at the CAS.

review_title: Great place to work depending on the department
pros: benefits as far as free education, great working environment if in the "right" department
cons: the location is not favorable if you live in metro atlanta

pros: This is a highly accomplished employer. Each employee is treated with respect and is made to feel important. Training is provided and easily available.
cons: I can not think of anything.

review_title: This job is ONLY for recent grads seeking  professional development opportunities and a "foot in the door".
pros: University issued car for travel, iPad, laptop, and phone.
cons: No opportunity for growth at the position.

job_title: Limited Term Instructor in Carrollton, GA
pros:
Encouragement to pursue passion within department
Friendly and helpful staff, faculty, and students both within department, college, and across campus
Beautiful campus
cons: Departmental organization could use some improvement

review_title: You don't do it for the pay
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Carrollton, GA
